node.title: Moose environment update
node.bodyText:
Hello:
I have tried both "conda update --all" and "mamba update --all" but don't get the latest version.  When I use "mamba list", it shows:
moose-libmesh             2022.06.06              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.1.0            py39hc1bf809_7    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpich               4.0.1                   build_2    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.16.5                  build_3    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2022.07.18       py39h5a31bc0_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public

Interestingly, when I issue the update command, a question mark appears in the folder icon at the top of the terminal window.  I have the following at the bottom of my .zshrc file:
# >>> conda initialize >>>
# !! Contents within this block are managed by 'conda init' !!
__conda_setup="$('/Users/joe/mambaforge3/bin/conda' 'shell.zsh' 'hook' 2> /dev/null)"
if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    eval "$__conda_setup"
else
    if [ -f "/Users/joe/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh" ]; then
        . "/Users/joe/mambaforge3/etc/profile.d/conda.sh"
    else
        export PATH="/Users/joe/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH"
    fi
fi
unset __conda_setup
# <<< conda initialize <<<

mamba activate moose

export HOST=$(hostname)

Before issuing the update command, the folder icon path shows as: "JMKs MBP/Macintosh HD/Users/joe".  But after issuing either the conda or mamba update command, it changes to: "x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0//Users/joe".
Thanks for the help,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
Never seen the issue with the folder icon.
When conda/mamba fails to update (mamba is a little better at the dependency resolution), it's worth deleting the environment and re-cloning it. If you still get the same packages that are lagging behind, the next culprit is usually the python version in the environment
Please let us know how it goes,
Guillaume

Thanks Guillaume.  Deleting the environment and reloading it did the trick.  I now have:
moose-libmesh             2022.09.09              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.1.0               he71d177_12    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpich               4.0.2                   build_2    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.16.6                  build_1    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2022.07.18      py310hcffbc79_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
That I believe are the most recent.
Thanks again,
Joe

same as me
moose-libmesh             2022.09.09              build_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-libmesh-vtk         9.1.0               h3f5ae15_12    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-mpich               4.0.2                   build_2    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-petsc               3.16.6                  build_1    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
moose-tools               2022.07.18      py310ha2ead4d_0    https://conda.software.inl.gov/public

node.title: Symmetry Axis in Axisymmetric Simulation
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm doing an axisymmatric simulation of a ring and want to define the y-axis as the symmetry axis. What I did in former simulations was just using a DirichletBC to stop displacements in x-direction on the left boundary. But now that I have a ring whose left boundary doesn't align with the symmetry axis I can't do that. Is there a way to tell MOOSE that my symmetry axis is 5 mm to the left of my left boundary?

I am a little bit confused, because it sounds like you want to utilize the axisymmetry and model a 3D cylinder in 2D, but you are still working with cartesian coordinates, e.g. x, y. Can I assume that you really meant to say the r-displacement instead of the x-displacement?
If so, then the solution will be very simple: you don't prescribe the left boundary in the r-direction.

Is there a way to tell MOOSE that my symmetry axis is 5 mm to the left of my left boundary?

The best way to achieve that is to have your symmetry axis go through the origin (0, 0). For example, let the bottom left corner of the mesh have an x-coordinate of 5 mm.

Yes, you are right. The correct way would be to use r and z. But when using the TensorMechanicsMasterAction the Syntax for the variables stays as x and y AFAIK.
Ok so if I understand you correctly MOOSE automatically assumes that there is a symmetry axis through (0,0)? So if I model the geometry as it is pictured above with the bottom left corner as (0,0), I'd fix the r-displacement on the left side of the stemp and the z-displacement on the bottom of the square and that would be it? No assigning a general symmetry axis in z-direction so the program knows the square is supposed to be a ring?

Yes, you are right. The correct way would be to use r and z. But when using the TensorMechanicsMasterAction the Syntax for the variables stays as x and y AFAIK.

Hmm that's interesting. You can see for example modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/2D_geometries/2D-RZ_test.i which uses disp_r, disp_z, stress_zz etc. The input file you were looking at probably is probably out-of-date, which we should fix...

Ok so if I understand you correctly MOOSE automatically assumes that there is a symmetry axis through (0,0)? So if I model the geometry as it is pictured above with the bottom left corner as (0,0), I'd fix the r-displacement on the left side of the stemp and the z-displacement on the bottom of the square and that would be it? No assigning a general symmetry axis in z-direction so the program knows the square is supposed to be a ring?

If the left boundary coincides with the symmetry axis, you may or may not fix the r-displacement there -- the solution will be identical.
If the left boundary does not coincide with the symmetry axis, you should not fix the r-displacement there.

Hmm that's interesting. You can see for example modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/2D_geometries/2D-RZ_test.i which uses disp_r, disp_z, stress_zz etc. The input file you were looking at probably is probably out-of-date, which we should fix...

Ah well, good to know.

If the left boundary coincides with the symmetry axis, you may or may not fix the r-displacement there -- the solution will be identical.
If the left boundary does not coincide with the symmetry axis, you should not fix the r-displacement there.

Ok yeah and the symmetry axis is automatically located on the z-axis?

Yes, I believe that is a fundamental assumption we make: In tensor_mechanics, the symmetry axis for an axisymmetric cylindrical coordinate system always goes through point (0, 0) and has direction (0, 1), speaking Cartesian.
Alright, thank you.

node.title: PorousFlow: Fault mechanics
node.bodyText:
Hi experts,
I am simulating a fault in a rock aquifer with PorousFlow (by the way, thanks for the five start code). The geometry is complex and hydro-mechanical coupled.
I am first trying to reach mechanical equilibrium in steady state. But the geometry is complex, looks like the strains and displacements are big and therefore the different layers loose contact. See attached. Is there any way to "glue" the different layers? Or perhaps the finite strain approach is not correct?

Cheers!
Wang

If i understand your model correctly, this is a mesh problem, not a problem with your model.
Your deformed model exhibits two "fractures" (the grey lines in the above figure) that should not be there.  Those grey lines will not allow fluid to flow across them, nor will they transmit any mechanical force.  This is because they are actually empty space (there are no thin finite elements that sit inside those "fractures").
If the previous paragraph is correct, then your mesh is at fault.  You have created a mesh that contains a "left block" a "fault block" and a "right block" (shown in the above figure).  However, these blocks do not share any nodes except for at the very top of the picture (and probably the bottom too).  They must share nodes, and then your model will not generate those grey fractures.  You'll have to go back to your meshing software and ensure the blocks share nodes.
a
Thanks!! This fixed the problem!!

node.title: The mesh generating for cohesive zone model (CZM)
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I am new  to CZM and when i study the example case in MOOSE :(moose/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/cohesive_zone_model/stretch_rotate_large_deformation.i),
I noticed that the mesh and the  interface (boundary = 'interface') was generated by using BreakMeshByBlockGenerator.

Now i want to generate the mesh in that case by using software Cubit. Whether just the boundary = 'interface' in inputfile need change to boundary = 'surface1 surface2' ,
or maybe i should merge  surface1  and  surface2 in Cubit and then set the surface as interface ?

An interface includes two opposite sides, e.g. a primary side and a secondary side. But the CZM implementation in tensor_mechanics operates on only one side of the interface. That was a design choice.
So in your case you should either provide boundary = 'surface1', or boundary = 'surface2', but not both. Also note that the mesh you supplied into MOOSE should be fully connected, i.e. the interface between surface1/surface2 is not disjoint. The splitting has to be handled by BreakMeshByBlockGenerator.

Also note that the mesh you supplied into MOOSE should be fully connected, i.e. the interface between surface1/surface2 is not disjoint. The splitting has to be handled by BreakMeshByBlockGenerator.

So i should merge  surface1 and surface2 to make volume1 and volume2 fully connected by using Cubit, and name them block1/block2, then use BreakMeshByBlockGenerator to split them?
Yes. The mesh generator has many options. I believe you can tune it to meet your needs. If not let me know.

If the mesh file created by Cubit has 3 merged blocks:

the cohesive zone model (CZM) is applied in volume1 and volume2, i.e. the BreakMeshByBlockGenerator only apply in block1 and block2, not block3. How could this be realized?
Use the 'block_pair' option. See https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/BreakMeshByBlockGenerator.html

node.title: Where can I find more info about the geometric search system?
node.bodyText:
When I read the introduction about the NearestNodeValueAux, it says"The NearestNodeValueAux uses the geometric search system to find the shortest distance from a node where the AuxVariable......".
I want to know more information about the geometric search system. And if possible, can anybody tell me how can I use this system?
Ethan

Hello
We have this documentation online
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/geomsearch/GeometricSearchData.html
Hope it helps
Guillaume

@GiudGiud Hello! It's an old disscusion :）
I want to know where I can find the info about the getQuadraturePenetrationLocator in GeometricSearchData. I want to express the coordinate of the quadrature points in Kernel.
Oh I find the GeometricSearchData.h and GeometricSearchData.C.

node.title: Auxiliary variables
node.bodyText:
Hello buddy,
I have a questions regarding the auxiliary variables.
I see the following words from the workshop "Auxiliary variables come in two flavors: Nodal and Elemental" and at the same time in the auxiliary kernel we wrote velocity expression in this way "-(_permeability[_qp] / _viscosity[_qp]) * _pressure_gradient[_qp]" where qp is the quadrature point.
It is difficult for me to link this quadrature point with Nodal and Elemental here. Could you please give an example that can intuitively illustrate the odal varaible and elemental variable?
Thank you in advance.
Kind regards,
Qiao

Hello
Elemental variables may have multiple quadrature points (CONSTANT MONOMIAL or cell-centered finite volume only have one). _qp indexing reaches the value computed for the relevant quadrature point. Auxkernels for elemental variables loop over elements, then have an inner loop on quadrature points.
Nodal variables use the nodes as quadrature points. So _qp is just 0
Re-using the same syntax for both allows us to write a single auxkernel definition that is valid for both nodal and elemental variables.
Guillaume

ok, one more question here, if we have a variable: "velocity", this velocity can be set as either elemental variable or nodal variable, right? or maybe it can only be nodal variable?
Another thing is for the _qp in the elemental variable case, it is numbered for each element for example, _qp =1,2,3. or _qp is numbered globally for all the elements?  Thank you again.

it could be either. In FE we use nodal variables for velocity, in FV we use an elemental one. The type of variable may influence what discretization you use of the equations (CG, DG etc)
it s numbered locally

it could be either. In FE we use nodal variables for velocity, in FV we use an elemental one. The type of variable may influence what discretization you use of the equations (CG, DG etc)
it s numbered locally

Hi Guillaume,
Here you mentioned that velocity is nodal variable in FE. Do you mean we compute velocity in the auxkernel at nodes? What if now I directly compute velocity (one of unknowns) from solving the model equations implicitly and simultaneously? Is it still nodal variable? then how does moose implement the quadrature integration? Thank you, I just recall some stuff in my mind.
Best regards,
Qiao

The quadrature points for nodal variables are the nodes.
Nodal variables may be auxiliary or nonlinear.
Quadrature points are actually not at nodes, but some loops in MOOSE over quadrature points can be re-used for nodal values, by just pretending the node is the only Qp

node.title: Can EBSDMeshGenerator be calculated using distributed mesh?
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Recently, I want to use EBSD data for the large-scale phase field simulation. However, I found that setting parallel_type = distributed in EBSDMeshGenerator  of IN100-111grn.i, and it shows the following error,
...
*** ERROR ***
/home/pw-moose/projects/luwu/grainGrowth/gNGs2022/ebsd_00/IN100-111grn.i:6: unused parameter 'Mesh/ebsd_mesh/parallel_type'
Then, the details of the output to th terminal are in 01.log
Therefore, my question is whether it is possible to use distributed mesh in EBSDMeshGenerator  to effectively reduce memory usage, or whether only replicated mesh can be used in EBSDMeshGenerator.
Any suggestions or recommendations to fix these problems would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks
wei peng

Parallel_type is a [Mesh] block parameter, not a [Mesh/some_generator] parameter
Looking at the code and the tests, distributed meshes are supported for this mesh generator.
You can either pass this parameter at the right location or add --distributed-mesh to the command line

Great, thank you for your reply. I solved the problem yesterday by modifying the code of EBSDMeshGenerator to set up the distributed mesh.
wei
nice!!

node.title: Moose example for crystal plasticity modeling under high/low cycle fatigue loading
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose experts or users,
Are there any developed Moose examples for crystal plasticity modeling under high/low cycle fatigue loading? My purpose is to predict the creep-fatigue life of polycrystal materials and study damage evolution. Any ideas or suggestions about that? Thank you.

Hi @xchengood ,
We do not have any examples of crystal plasticity models being used in fatigue loading within the MOOSE repository currently. I do believe, however, that some research groups may their own branches with these types of models. Perhaps @ngrilli is one of these people?

Hi @sapitts. Thank you for your reply. How do I create a low or high cycle loading in Moose? If I want to build a user object, do you have any advice (e.g. base class)?
@ngrilli, It would be helpful if you could share any built code examples about the creep-fatigue model. Thank you.

@xchengood an example of backstress implementation is here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/materials/FiniteStrainCrystalPlasticityBackstress.C
which you will need for cyclic fatigue I guess.
An example of creep implementation is here:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/materials/CrystalPlasticityDislocationUpdate.C
If you tell us which specific model and material you want to implement, we can help better,
if you are unsure where to start, a Chaboche model may be a good starting point.
Best Regards,
Nicolò

node.title: location of temporary runtime files
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
When running MOOSE, it creates temporary files along the lines of "tmp_jit_HOyNo6.so".  Is it possible to specify the location of those files?
a

Hello
I dont know that you can. @dschwen will know for sure
There's some paramters to get rid of them, disable_fpoptimizer I think
they are under Advanced
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/DerivativeParsedMaterial.html
Guillaume
Thank you @GiudGiud

May I ask why you need this? If you have the ability to control where these files are created, it may help others.
Others that have in the past, wished to maintain a centralized location of MOOSE source where multiple people 'build' from, yet don't have write access.

My HPC staff asked whether this was possible, because they think that writing lots of these temporary files causes the filesystem to slowdown for everyone (I'm running many MOOSE jobs).  If i could write to another filesystem then it would help address that slowdown.
a

node.title: Can MOOSE make several discrete values into a new variable?
node.bodyText: I use the NodalValueSampler and get the values of the specific variable at each node in a specific 1D-block(in the form of array). Now I want to make these values into a new variable and at the same time the nodal values of the new variable are the elements of the array I get. How can achieve it?

not sure how to do it cleanly.
seems parsedAux wont let you use a postprocessor
you could put it in a VectorPostprocessor and then use this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/site/source/auxkernels/VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux.html
but there's got to be another way
Thanks a lot for your apply! I will have a try.And If I find some other way to achieve it I will tell you.

@GiudGiud Hello! I notice that the VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux reads values from a VectorPostprocessor that is producing vectors that are 'number of processors' * in length. So VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux is used to put the value for each processor into auxiliary field. But to be honest, I'm not so familiar with the info about the processor in MOOSE. There is only one processor in my input file and what I want is to put the vector which I get from the VectorPostprocessor(NodalValueSampler) into auxiliary field.
Should I change the source code of the VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux to achieve my goal?

@GiudGiud I've used the VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux and I wrote an input file. But it shows an error:
*** **ERROR** ***
**The following error occurred in the object "AuxVELADJ", of type "VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux".
Error in AuxKernel AuxVELADJ. Vector u in VectorPostprocessor VELADJ_VEC does not contain num_procs number of entries.  num_procs: 1 num_entries: 0**
Here is my input file:
[GlobalParams]
  gravity = -9.8
  transient_term = false
[]

[Mesh]
 file = 'twopipe.e'
[]

[Variables]
  [./p]
    order = SECOND
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = '1 2'
  [../]
  [./u]
    order = SECOND
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = '1 2'
    [./InitialCondition]
      type = ConstantIC
      value = 0.5
    [../]
  [../]
  [./T]
    order = SECOND
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = '1 2'
    [./InitialCondition]
      type = ConstantIC
      value = 628
    [../]
  [../]
  [./w]
    order = SECOND
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = '1'
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./VELADJ]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  [../]
  [./PRESSADJ]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  [../]
  [./RHOADJ]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  [../]
[]
[AuxKernels]
 [./AuxVELADJ]
   type = VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux
   vpp = VELADJ_VEC
   vector_name = u
   variable = VELADJ
   execute_on = 'LINEAR NONLINEAR'
 [../]
 [./AuxPRESSADJ]
   type = VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux
   vpp = PRESSADJ_VEC
   vector_name = p
   variable = PRESSADJ
   execute_on = 'LINEAR NONLINEAR'
 [../]
 [./AuxRHOADJ]
   type = VectorPostprocessorVisualizationAux
   vpp = RHOADJ_VEC
   vector_name = 'rho'
   variable = RHOADJ
   execute_on = 'LINEAR NONLINEAR'
 [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./MASS_EQUATION]
    type = mass
    variable = p
    vel = u
    temp = T
    press = p
    block = '1 2'
  [../]

    block = '1 2'

    lvel = w

    press = p
    veladj = VELADJ
    pressadj = PRESSADJ
    rhoadj = RHOADJ
    block = '1'

    sk = 0.5

  [../]
[]

[Functions]

    value = 1.0e8*sin(pi*x)
  [../]
[../]

[BCs]
  [./outlet_p]
    type =  DirichletBC
    boundary = '16 26'
    variable = p
    value = 2.0e5
  [../]

    value = 1

[]

I don't know why the num_entries is 0.

The NodalValueSampler isnt going to have 1 entry. It ll have a lot. Not sure why it s reporting 0.
I would use a postprocessor to get the value you wasnt, then convert it to a VPP using the VectorOfPostprocessors vpp.
Anyway, I think we may be astray here.
You're just trying to copy a variable into another variable right?
Both the ParsedAux and SelfAux can do that

Actually the "variable" and the "another variable" are from different blocks. The [Variable] and [Kernel] block in MOOSE are all block-restrictable. So I meet this problem when I try to express "variable in another block" in the current block. And why I have to do that is because the equation which I want to solve is semiempirical. The equation is independent of grid.
All in all, thank you a lot for your patience! I will try SelfAux first.

ah ok.
Can they be split in a different calculation using the MultiApp system?
This is typically how we do this.
SelfAux would only work if they were defined on the same blocks
